title: 104_hr1100
content: The "Federal Election Law Reform Commission Act" establishes the Federal Election Law Reform Commission to study and recommend reforms in laws related to elections for Federal office. The Federal Election Law Reform Commission is composed of 8 members appointed by the President, with advice and consent of the Senate, who are not government officers and are qualified by education, training, or experience. The President consults various leaders for appointments, and designates one member as Chairman of the Commission. The Federal Election Law Reform Commission consists of 8 members appointed by the President, with one member designated as Chairman. Members serve for the life of the Commission, vacancies are filled in the same manner as the original appointment, and no more than 4 members can be of the same political party. The Federal Election Law Reform Commission, consisting of 8 members appointed by the President, has the power to hold hearings, take testimony, and receive evidence. A quorum of five members is required for hearings, and the Commission must submit a report with recommended legislation to Congress within one year of enactment. SEC. 6. MATTERS TO BE CONSIDERED BY THE COMMISSION. The Commission formulating draft legislation under section 5 shall consider growth patterns of expenditures in Federal elections, public financing options, expenditure limitations for campaign resource balance, and enforcement mechanisms like voluntary compliance incentives and mandatory penalties for excess expenditures. The Commission drafting legislation under section 5 will examine various aspects of election spending, including the impact of political action committees, limitations on contributions, independent expenditures, and the regulation of "soft money" used for party activities. The Commission drafting legislation under section 5 will examine the impact of out-of-State and out-of-District contributions on congressional elections. SEC. 7. FAST-TRACK PROCEDURES. The section outlines rules for the House of Representatives and Senate, stating that they have the power to make rules that supersede others if inconsistent. It also acknowledges the right of each House to change rules relating to them. The term "Federal election bill" is defined as a bill introduced in Congress to carry out specific procedures. The Federal election bill, introduced as provided in subsection (c) to implement Commission recommendations, must be introduced in the House and Senate within 3 days. No amendments are allowed to the bill in either House, and there is a specified period for committee and floor consideration. If a Federal election bill is not reported by the committee within 20 days of its introduction, the committee will be discharged from further consideration. If both Houses receive the same Federal election bill, the vote on final passage will be on the bill from the other House. In the House, a motion to proceed to consider a Federal election bill is highly privileged and can only be made on the second legislative day after announcement. The motion is not debatable, and amendments or reconsideration of the vote are not allowed. In the House, consideration of a Federal election bill is limited to 10 hours with equal debate time for supporters and opponents. The bill will proceed to final passage without a reconsideration vote. Appeals on House Rules related to the bill are decided without debate. Floor Consideration in the Senate for a Federal election bill is privileged and not debatable. Debate is limited to 10 hours, divided between majority and minority leaders. Debates on motions or appeals are limited to 1 hour. Floor Consideration in the Senate for a Federal election bill is privileged and not debatable. Debate is limited to 10 hours, divided between majority and minority leaders. A motion to further limit debate is not debatable, and a motion to recommit a Federal election bill is not in order. Time for debates on motions or appeals is limited to 1 hour, with control divided between the mover, bill manager, and minority leader if the bill manager is in favor of the motion. Additional time can be allotted by the leaders during consideration of any debatable motion or appeal. SEC. 8. ADMINISTRATIVE PROVISIONS. Members of the Commission are paid based on their level, with the Chairman receiving a higher rate. They also receive travel expenses as per regulations. The Commission appoints a staff director independently. The Commission appoints a staff director who is paid at the rate of level IV of the Executive Schedule. The Director can appoint additional personnel without following the usual appointment procedures and pay regulations, with a salary limit of grade GS-15 of the General Schedule. The Commission can detail personnel from federal departments on a reimbursable basis to assist in its duties. It can also hire experts or consultants through contracts as needed. The Commission will dissolve 3 months after submitting its report. Appropriations are authorized for the Commission to fulfill its duties.
